description:
In Guyana, The Ministry of Education wishes to advise that with effect from Monday, March 16, 2020, all schools will be closed for two weeks. This was later extended on March 23rd in another announcement. The extended closure of schools is April 3, which will lead into the Easter Term vacation which runs from April 06, 2020 – April 17, 2020. Schools are set to reopen on April 20.

The University of Guyana (UG) has also extended its closure to March 30th. No updates on opening have been issued for now.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)

description:
In Guyana, the Minister of Public Health has issued emergency measures to contain the spread of the Novel Coronavirus.

It will be in effect from April 3 to May 3, 2020. These measures, among other things, supervised the implementation of a 6 pm to 6 am curfew while only catering for the operations of essential services on a 24-hour basis.

With these emergency measures now published all curfews or measures taken by town councils and village/community leaders and others are revoked except those made by the Ministers responsible for Education, Civil Aviation, Maritime, Immigration and Finance.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
In Guyana, the Minister of Public Health has issued emergency measures to contain the spread of the Novel Coronavirus.

UPDATE: Curfew extended to June 3
It will be in effect from April 3 to May 3, 2020. These measures, among other things, supervised the implementation of a 6 pm to 6 am curfew while only catering for the operations of essential services on a 24-hour basis.

With these emergency measures now published all curfews or measures taken by town councils and village/community leaders and others are revoked except those made by the Ministers responsible for Education, Civil Aviation, Maritime, Immigration and Finance. UPDATE: The curfew has been extended for another month. The updated COVID-19 Emergency Measures states that this takes effect from May 4 until June 3, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
In Guyana, the Minister of Public Health has issued emergency measures to contain the spread of the Novel Coronavirus.

It will be in effect from April 3 to May 3, 2020. These measures, among other things, supervised the implementation of a 6 pm to 6 am curfew while only catering for the operations of essential services on a 24-hour basis.

With these emergency measures now published all curfews or measures taken by town councils and village/community leaders and others are revoked except those made by the Ministers responsible for Education, Civil Aviation, Maritime, Immigration and Finance. UPDATE: The COVID-19 Emergency Measures effective until June 3, 2020, has been extended to 17 June 2020, as advised by the National COVID-19 Task Force.
This also means the 6pm-6am curfew will remain in effect until 17 June 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
In Guyana, the Minister of Public Health has issued emergency measures to contain the spread of the Novel Coronavirus.

It will be in effect from April 3 to May 3, 2020. These measures, among other things, supervised the implementation of a 6 pm to 6 am curfew while only catering for the operations of essential services on a 24-hour basis.

With these emergency measures now published all curfews or measures taken by town councils and village/community leaders and others are revoked except those made by the Ministers responsible for Education, Civil Aviation, Maritime, Immigration and Finance. UPDATE: The National COVID-19 Task Force has announced that Phase 3 of Guyana’s re-opening process. The national curfew will now be from 8pm (instead of 6pm) to 6am. The curfew shall not apply in Regions 5 and 6 on Mondays to Fridays but shall be in effect on Saturdays and Sundays in these two regions. Outdoor dining at restaurants will be permitted from 6am to 6pm under strict conditions
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Police,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
In Guyana, the Minister of Public Health has issued emergency measures to contain the spread of the Novel Coronavirus.

It will be in effect from April 3 to May 3, 2020. These measures, among other things, supervised the implementation of a 6 pm to 6 am curfew while only catering for the operations of essential services on a 24-hour basis.

With these emergency measures now published all curfews or measures taken by town councils and village/community leaders and others are revoked except those made by the Ministers responsible for Education, Civil Aviation, Maritime, Immigration and Finance. UPDATE: National COVID-19 Task Force has announced a six-phase re-opening of Guyana commencing with Phase 1. 
The current curfew of 6pm to 6am will remain in effect for Phase 1 in all administrative regions. The non-curfew measures will be lifted in Regions 5 and 8
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
In Guyana, the Minister of Public Health has issued emergency measures to contain the spread of the Novel Coronavirus.

It will be in effect from April 3 to May 3, 2020. These measures, among other things, supervised the implementation of a 6 pm to 6 am curfew while only catering for the operations of essential services on a 24-hour basis.

With these emergency measures now published all curfews or measures taken by town councils and village/community leaders and others are revoked except those made by the Ministers responsible for Education, Civil Aviation, Maritime, Immigration and Finance. UPDATE: Phase two of the National COVID-19 Task Force’s six-phase plan to reopen Guyana commences. For Phase 2, all allowances and measures in Phase 1 will be maintained with permission being granted to the manufacturing sector, public sector, construction and medical schools to operate during the non-curfew hours. The 6pm to 6am curfew remains in effect in all administrative regions.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Police,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: Guyana to partially close airports amid Coronavirus outbreak. Director General of the Guyana Civil Aviation Authority (GCAA) Egbert Fields has announced that airports in the country will be partially shutdown, effective Wednesday, March 18, 2020 – due to the Coronavirus outbreak.The closure will take effect at midnight and will last for 14 days. The shutdown will mainly apply to incoming international passenger flights at the Cheddi Jagan International Airport (CJIA) and Eugene F Correira International Airport.The shutdown will not apply to outgoing flights, cargo flights, medevac flights, technical flights, and any other specially authorized flights.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Guyana’s Cheddi Jagan International Airport (CJIA) and the Eugene Correia International Airport (ECIA) will remain closed to international flights until May 1, 2020. UPDATE: Announced by the Ministry of Public Infrastructure’s social media platforms, Guyana’s Cheddi Jagan International Airport (CJIA) and the Eugene Correia International Airport (ECIA) will remain closed to international flights until May 1, 2020. The closure was previously till April 1st week.

description:
In Guyana, the former Ocean View Hotel located on the Rupert Craig Highway, Liliendaal will be used as a dedicated COVID-19 facility to treat and monitor patients. The facility will house 300 critical patient once it is operational.

Other facilities that are being prepared for COVID -19 treatment are  the former Guyana Broadcasting Corporation building on High Street, the National Gymnasium and the Cliff Anderson Sports Hall. The various COVID-19 facilities will cater for over 1000 patients.

description:
In Guyana, the Ministry of Public Health will soon launch an App that will allow persons to self-test for COVID-19. This is expected to be rolled out on April 5, 2020, on the National Communications Network.

With the app, persons can test themselves for the virus, after which the information will go directly to the surveillance team. After self-testing, persons will be contacted by the surveillance team once they fit any of the following scenarios.

1. If you have traveled and during the 14 days you begin to have a cough, fever or shortness of breath
2. If you have been in contact with someone who has tested positive for COVID-19 and during 14 days since that meeting you begin to have – a cough, fever or shortness of breath.
3. If you visited a facility where COVID-19 positive cases have been identified and during the 14 days after that visit you begin to have a cough, fever or shortness of breath
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
Start date: 4/7/20

On April 7, 2020, the Guyana Revenue Authority (GRA) today announced a range of additional tax relief measures that will assist Guyanese as the country grapples with the fight against the COVID-19 pandemic.

The tax relief, the entity stated, will support businesses and individuals who have been socially and economically disadvantaged by the threat of the virus.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_text: The measures included in this reduction of tax focussed policy are: Removal of VAT on Water and Electricity with effect from April 01, 2020, to June 30, 2020. Removal of VAT on Domestic Air Travel with effect from April 08, 2020, to June 30, 2020. Extension of the April 30 deadline for the filing of tax returns to June 30, 2020. The waiver of VAT and duties on COVID 19 medical supplies and lab testing kits. The granting of tax deductions for all donations made by local businesses to staff and health institutions for the treatment of the virus.
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

Inmates in Guyana have begun to be released to address overcrowding in the prisons in light of the COVID-19 pandemic.

~

Start date: 11/15/20

The Guyana Prison Service (GPS) has released 65 non-violent offenders in keeping with efforts to reduce overcrowding in all prisons and help minimise the spread of the coronavirus in the country’s jails. In October, more than 290 inmates at the Lusignan Prison had tested positive for the disease.  Several Prison Officers  had been also infected. UPDATE: Addressing overcrowding in prisons, the original policy was extended 18 November
~

description:
In keeping with safeguards to prevent an outbreak, more than a dozen family members of Guyana’s first novel coronavirus [COVID-19] victim (confirmed on March 11, 2020) are quarantined. This was confirmed by 
the Public Relations and Health Promotion Officer within the Ministry of Public Health, Mr. Terrence Esseboom on March 12. UPDATE: Arriving passengers will be expected to wear their facial masks at all times. Travelers with negative PCR test results will undergo a 7-day quarantine period. Other travellers who had the PCR test done on the day of flight and the results are not available will be subject to 14 days quarantine
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description:
In Guyana, the Bartica Town Council has put into effect a “Stay Home” advisory as of 18:00hrs (6 pm) on March 28, 2020.

“It is not a curfew; it is not a lockdown…. But we are calling on all Barticians and by extension the residents of Region Seven to do two things; be on the road for work purposes only and two only be on the road to access essential services,” Mayor Marshall said.

The advisory will be in effect for two weeks from March 28 to April 10, 2020. The orders which take effect from 6pm March 28 are as follows:

-The immediate closure of all public sporting venues utilized for sports and recreation namely the Bartica Sports Complex, Mongrippa playfield, other recreational parks.
- Closure of taxi parks, bus parks, and taxi catchment points.
- To ensure social distancing is being implemented  the advisory also recommends that there is no gathering at bars, restaurants and barbershops or salons; proprietors must engage customers through minimal contact options.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is closed/locked down

description:
Start date: 4/2/20

In Guyana, the Georgetown Mayor and City Council will be closing all municipal markets effective from Saturday, April 4, 2020, as it continues to implement temporary measures to put an end the spread of the novel coronavirus.

A public notice issued by the Municipality’s Markets Department on Thursday stated that all markets and street vending operations must cease from Friday, April 3, 2020, at 7pm.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: In Guyana, National COVID-19 Task Force held an emergency multi-stakeholder meeting on the alarming increase in confirmed COVID-19 cases in parts of regions 1 and 7. Decisions were taken to implement enhanced containment measures within the affected areas. These include ceasing work orders for specific areas in the mining sector, screening, wider testing, checkpoints, and other measures in several locations within regions 1 and 7.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
In Guyana, all ‘in person’ hearings have been suspended until further notice.
“These updated directions in relation to the COVID-19 pandemic are in addition to the Supreme Court of Judicature Practice Directions COVID-19 Emergency Directions, Gazetted on 23rd March, 2020.” The Supreme Court stated in a media release.
With immediate effect, the court said these measures will be in place lasting until April 24, 2020.

description:
In Guyana, The Protected Areas Commission (PAC) and the National Parks Commission (NPC) at this time would like to advise the general public that the Georgetown Zoo will be closed beginning Tuesday 17th March 2020 until further notice.

Please be advised also that the Botanical Gardens and the National Park will remain open as we take extra precautionary measures to ensure that all of our public facilities are fully sanitized.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: In Guyana, President David Granger, on Thursday (2nd April), announced that in order to strengthen containment measures against COVID-19, with effect from midnight (23:59 hours) on Friday 3rd April 2020, the government will close public gathering at places of entertainment, including bars, clubs, gymnasiums, night clubs, restaurants, and swimming pools, between the hours of 18:00 hours and 06:00 hours (6:00 pm and 6 am).

description:
In Guyana, The Protected Areas Commission (PAC) and the National Parks Commission (NPC) at this time would like to advise the general public that the Georgetown Zoo will be closed beginning Tuesday 17th March 2020 until further notice.

Please be advised also that the Botanical Gardens and the National Park will remain open as we take extra precautionary measures to ensure that all of our public facilities are fully sanitized. UPDATE: Guyana's Protected Areas Commission said that the national park will open from 6:30 am to 5 pm Monday to Friday but will remain closed on weekends.

description: In Guyana, to protect our senior citizens during this period when they are the most vulnerable to the Coronavirus (COVID-19), we are working to implement standardized measures across the Post Offices in every region to treat with the potential threat of the virus effectively.Of grave concern to the management of the Guyana Post Office Corporation (GPOC), is the trend of thousands of senior citizens accessing pension payments during the first and second day of the new month. We are therefore vehemently encouraging senior citizens to refrain from visiting the Post Offices during the first two days of the month unless it is absolutely necessary. Senior citizens can also authorize their family members to uplift their pension payments.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
